choices.text: Stenson’s duct opens behind upper 3rd molar

questions.text: True statement about Marked structure is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Explanation: Parotid gland • Largest salivary gland • Purely serous gland • The facial nerve forms the parotid plexus within the gland and separates the glandular tissue partially into superficial and deep layers ("lobes"). • Duct opens opposite upper 2nd molar • Lymph nodes occur in the skin overlying the parotid gland (preauricular nodes) and in the substance of the gland • Benign as well as malignant tumours may arise

questions.text: Identify the muscle shown in figure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Marked muscle is Abd Pollicis Brevis The Abductor Pollicis Brevis (APB) is a muscle in the hand that plays a key role in thumb movement. It is one of the thenar muscles, located at the base of the thumb, and its primary function is to abduct the thumb, which means it moves the thumb away from the palm, contributing to the thumb's range of motion. This action is important for grasping and manipulating objects. The APB originates from the flexor retinaculum and the scaphoid and trapezium bones in the wrist. It inserts into the proximal phalanx of the thumb. Innervated by the median nerve, it works in coordination with other muscles in the hand to provide dexterity and precision, especially in tasks that involve pinching or grasping. Dysfunction or weakness of the APB can lead to difficulties in performing these tasks, often seen in conditions like carpal tunnel syndrome, where compression of the median nerve affects thumb movements.

choices.text: Supplies the skin over the parotid gland.
Supplies the lower part of the pinna on its inner surface.
It is a motor nerve to muscles of facial expression.
Supplies the skin over the mastoid process.

questions.text: False statement about the marked structure is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A. Supplies the skin over the parotid gland: True. The great auricular nerve ascends over the sternocleidomastoid muscle and typically supplies the skin over the parotid gland. B. Supplies the lower part of the pinna on its inner surface: True. The great auricular nerve provides sensory innervation to the lower two-thirds of the auricle, including both its lateral (outer) and medial (inner) surfaces. C. It is a motor nerve to muscles of facial expression: FALSE. The Great Auricular Nerve is a purely sensory nerve. The facial nerve (CN VII) is the motor nerve to the muscles of facial expression. D. Supplies the skin over the mastoid process: True. The great auricular nerve also provides sensory innervation to the skin overlying the mastoid process behind the auricle.

choices.text: It is connected to cavernous sinus via Sup. Petrosal sinus

questions.text: False statement about the marked structure is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The image shows a sagittal view of the human skull, with a red arrow pointing to the transverse sinus. The question asks to identify the false statement regarding this marked structure. Option C: It receives Vein of Galen. This statement is false because the Great Cerebral Vein (of Galen) primarily drains into the straight sinus, not directly into the transverse sinus. The straight sinus then typically joins the superior sagittal sinus and the transverse sinuses at the confluence of sinuses (torcula Herophili). While the transverse sinus is part of the larger venous drainage system that eventually carries blood originating from the Vein of Galen, it does not directly receive the Vein of Galen as its immediate tributary. Let's examine why the other options are correct statements about the transverse sinus: Option A: It is connected to cavernous sinus via Sup. Petrosal sinus. This statement is correct. The superior petrosal sinus drains blood from the cavernous sinus and empties into the transverse sinus or into the junction of the transverse and sigmoid sinuses. Therefore, the transverse sinus is indeed connected to the cavernous sinus via the superior petrosal sinus. Option B: It continues as Sigmoid sinus. This statement is correct. The transverse sinus curves inferiorly and anteriorly along the temporal bone to become the sigmoid sinus. The sigmoid sinus then passes through the jugular foramen to become the internal jugular vein. This anatomical continuity is a fundamental aspect of dural venous sinus drainage. Option D: It is connected to Vein of Labbe. This statement is correct. The Vein of Labbe, also known as the inferior anastomotic vein, connects the superficial middle cerebral vein (which drains into the cavernous sinus) to the transverse sinus, thereby providing an important anastomotic pathway for venous drainage from the cerebral hemispheres.
